job_title: Registered Nurse in Long Beach, CA
pros:
Evidence-based medicine and quality patient care are very important to management.
Unit managers are very accommodating for time off.
Close-knit atmosphere and pleasant coworkers are a plus.
This hospital has plenty of free parking and is situated in a very nice area.
It is often possible to pick up an extra shift in one's own unit.
Education is promoted, which includes access to CINAHL databases and 12 hours of paid in-person classes for free.
This is a wonderful hospital for new grads because the most acute patients are shipped to Long Beach Memorial. 
Very clean facility.
Non-profit company, so they focus on serving the community, rather than profits.  This is evident in little ways, such as patient-centered care, allowing a little OT when something unexpected comes up, looking at new units/departments to serve patients in the community.
cons:
MemorialCare promotes the idea that employees can transfer to any facility after working for 6 months, but it is not possible to actually obtain a transfer to other facilities.  Ambitious people beware.
Cross-training to other units within facility is not authorized.
Pay is a bit lower here than at Long Beach Memorial.

review_title: Favoritism, Bullying, extremely busy and understaffed.  Pay should be better.

job_title: Clinical Professional in Long Beach, CA
pros: If you want to feel similar compassion and passion when working with pediatric patients, the MCH is the place for you! Everyone loves and cares for their patients, from the custodial staff, PCAs, RNs, receptionists, MDs, SWs, etc. The comradery is evident b/c the team cares for one another and you know people have your back. It's a fun place to work too b/c the majority of the staff are funny and like to laugh (when appropriate) to lighten the mood of working in an acute medical setting. There are a lot of sharp, intelligent, and caring people here, many of whom have worked hard and have been committed to the organization for a long time!
cons: There seems to be a significant lack of critical-thinking involved in administrators/management. LEAN projects are being implemented, but there's a lack of assessing whether or not it is actually efficient, creating "less-waste", and most importantly if it's beneficial to the patient/families. More work is being placed on RNs to be "coordinators of care" but it's actually making it worse for the patients b/c RNs are given more non-clinical tasks to manage which makes their clinical tasks harder to manage. Communication across disciplines is also TERRIBLE and that seems to be the culture here, but no one is trying to address effective solutions. Lastly, there are a few doctors who need to be confronted of their god-complex. No one should ever have to fear doctors, and some, have created a culture where they think they think it's okay to yell and intimidate people.
